Their use has revealed that fperm activate medaka fish eggs3 (as well as
other eggs on the vertebrate line by detonating a huge, traveling calcium
explosion or tsunami which moves across an egg at about 10 um/sec. More
recently, they have been used to reveal remarkable, periodic post-fertilization
waves of still unknown function. In the ascidian egg, most of these start from
the vegetal pole.5
They have also been used to reveal an apparent steady standing gradignt of
free calcium with its high point at the vegetal pole of medaka fish eggs. In
fucoid eggs, such a gradient--with the high calcium region at the future growth
or rhizoid pole--has long been postulated to help establish the main develop-
mental axis. Recent support for this hypothesis comes from the results of
microinjecting various buffers.
The development of such 'baptized' eggs is arrested for periods of up to
two weeks. Moreover, the relative effectiveness of BAPTA buffers of different
dissociation constants or KDS can be determined from the minimum buffer
concentration needed to arrest development. So far, the weaker the buffer, the
less must be injected. Thus the newly 5,5' 
a KD of 70 UM--is about 100 times more effective than 5,5' dimethyBAPTA which
has a KD of 0.4 UM. These results suggest that the needed calcium hot spot is
at a remarkably high level--perhaps 100 uM or more.7
